;飓风奥蒂斯于周三抵达墨西哥南部海岸，目前的 4 级风暴带来的破坏性飓风正在向内陆海滩度假村蔓延美国国家飓风中心 (NHC) 表示，阿卡普尔科的飓风强度已从 5 级降级。

;

;飓风抵达阿卡普尔科附近的陆地，并正在向墨西哥南部移动，带来强降雨和山洪暴发。 NHC 最新通报称，飓风强度大风。

;

;这场风暴可能会给格雷罗州和瓦哈卡州部分地区带来高达 20 英寸（51 厘米）的降雨，并可能引发山洪和泥石流，当局表示，“潜在的灾难性”风暴潮以及“危及生命”的海浪和离岸流状况。

;

;墨西哥国家水务局 CONAGUA 警告称，阿卡普尔科所在地格雷罗州附近海浪高达 6 至 8 米- 以及瓦哈卡州部分地区。

;

;总部位于迈阿密的 NHC 补充道，奥蒂斯位于阿卡普尔科西北方向约 25 英里处，最大持续风速为 130 英里/小时（215 公里/小时）。

;

;在格雷罗州，当局正在准备避难所，国民警卫队表示正在帮助准备救援和疏散。

;

;墨西哥国家民防协调中心 (CNPC) 表示，由于飓风，格雷罗州各地都出现停电情况。周二晚些时候，总统安德烈斯·曼努埃尔·洛佩兹·奥夫拉多尔在社交媒体上表示，国防部在风暴到来之前制定了一项灾难计划，当时士兵们正在阿卡普尔科空无一人的海滩上巡逻。

;

;学校州长伊芙琳·萨尔加多在社交媒体上表示，格雷罗州在奥蒂斯抵达之前取消了周三的课程。

;

;以色列军方加强了对南部地区的轰炸加沙一夜之间经历了自冲突开始以来巴勒斯坦人死亡最严重的日子之一，国际社会呼吁暂停战斗，让援助进入飞地并防止更多人死亡。

;

;加沙卫生官员周三表示，南部又有数十人被杀，以色列警告他们将袭击北部，以消灭 10 月 7 日在以色列发动杀戮的哈马斯武装分子后，数十万人逃离。

;

;一次罢工摧毁了汗尤尼斯的几栋公寓楼。居民哈德尔·阿布·奥达 (Khader Abu Odah) 说：“这很不正常，我们以前从未听说过这样的事情。”

;

;巴勒斯坦人对杀戮的愤怒因许多服从命令的人的背叛感而加剧。令南迁者亦被杀。以色列军方表示，统治加沙的哈马斯已在各地平民中根深蒂固。

;

;以色列表示，过去 24 小时内对加沙的袭击已消灭了哈马斯特工，其中包括哈马斯南部营的负责人。 Khan Younis、Tayseer Bebasher。

;

;军方补充说，隧道竖井、指挥中心、武器储藏处和发射阵地以及试图从齐基姆基布兹附近海上进入以色列的哈马斯潜水员小组都成为目标。< /p>;

;在北部加沙城，救援人员从废墟中救出一名显然已经毫无生命迹象的年幼儿童，然后试图安抚一名焦躁、半埋的男子，他大声喊出家人的名字。

;

;“他们是好吧，我发誓，”一名救援人员在现场视频中说道。

;

;以色列军方表示，以色列战机还袭击了叙利亚军队的基础设施，以回应从伊朗盟友叙利亚发射的火箭弹，这引发了人们的担忧叙利亚国家通讯社称，以色列在西南部城市德拉附近发动袭击，造成 8 名士兵死亡，另外 7 名士兵受伤。

;以色列没有指责叙利亚军队发射这两枚火箭，这两枚火箭在以色列占领的戈兰高地引发了空袭警报，也没有提供涉嫌肇事者的详细信息。

;

;;伊朗数十年来一直寻求地区优势并支持叙利亚的武装团体，黎巴嫩和其他地方以及哈马斯已警告以色列停止对加沙的攻击。<​​/p>;

;发言人海军少将丹尼尔·哈加里 (Daniel Hagari) 表示，以色列军队袭击了黎巴嫩境内准备反装甲导弹袭击或火箭发射的五个小队。< /p>;

;黎巴嫩伊朗支持的真主党组织表示，又有 4 名武装分子被杀，自冲突开始以来，该组织的死亡人数已增至 42 人。

;

;美国和俄罗斯国际社会正在带头呼吁以色列和哈马斯暂停战斗，以便向生活条件艰苦的加沙提供援助。

;

;周六，埃及重新开始通过拉法运送有限的食品、药品和水。该过境点不受以色列控制，以色列宣布在本月遭受哈马斯袭击后，已永久封锁该沿海飞地。

;

;周二晚间，又有 20 辆卡车在延误后通过，但联合国机构表示，已逾 20 次通过该过境点。即使在和平时期，这个狭窄的沿海地带的 230 万人也严重依赖援助，他们非常需要援助。

;

;华盛顿希望短暂暂停以允许援助进入，而俄罗斯则主张更广泛的停战。以色列迄今对这两种行动均予以抵制，认为哈马斯只会利用这一点，对其平民制造新的威胁。

;

;哈马斯武装分子于 10 月 7 日袭击以色列南部城镇，造成 1,400 人死亡，随后以色列对加沙发动了袭击，其中大多数是平民，并劫持了 200 多人作为人质。

;

;哈马斯统治的加沙卫生部称，周二共有 704 名巴勒斯坦人被杀，其中包括 305 名儿童。联合国人道主义事务协调办公室表示，这是冲突中单日死亡人数最高的一次。

;

;以色列军队和巴勒斯坦人在被占领的约旦河西岸的冲突也加剧，造成超过 10 人死亡。巴勒斯坦卫生部表示，有 100 名巴勒斯坦人死亡。

;

;加沙卫生部周二表示，自 10 月 7 日以来，至少有 5,791 名巴勒斯坦人在以色列对飞地的轰炸中丧生，其中包括 2,360 名儿童。

;

;联合国人道主义事务协调办公室表示，加沙超过三分之一的医院和近三分之二的初级卫生诊所因损坏或缺乏燃料而关闭。

;

;近东救济工程处、联合国巴勒斯坦难民机构警告说，如果不允许燃料供应进入，该机构将不得不在周三晚上停止在加沙的行动，因为燃料将耗尽。

;

;但是，以色列军方周二重申，将< a href="/world/middle-east/un-says-no-aid-trucks-enter-gaza-tuesday-2023-10-24/">;禁止燃料进入;，以防止哈马斯夺取燃料.

; Wed, 25 Oct 2023 18:55:02 +0800 Russia passes law pulling ratification of nuclear test ban treatyhttps://reuters.com/article/nuclear-russia/russia-passes-law-pulling-ratification-of-nuclear-test-ban-treaty-idUSKBN31P0NL
;;2023-10-25T09:56:26Z;
;

;俄罗斯议会周三完成了一项法律的通过，撤回了对禁止核武器试验的全球条约的批准，这证明了随着莫斯科在乌克兰发动战争，与美国的关系陷入深度冷淡。

;

;外交部副部长谢尔盖·里亚布科夫表示，除非华盛顿放弃其“敌对”政策，否则俄罗斯不准备恢复与美国讨论核问题。

;

;废除《全面禁止核试验条约》(CTBT) 的法案在众议院以 156 票对零票通过，众议院也一致通过。现在该协议已交由弗拉基米尔·普京总统签署。

;

;普京要求做出修改，以“反映”美国的立场，美国于 1996 年签署了《全面禁止核试验条约》，但从未批准。

;

;虽然从未正式生效，但《全面禁核试条约》已将核试验视为禁忌——本世纪除朝鲜以外没有任何国家进行过涉及核爆炸的试验。

;

;俄罗斯表示，除非有必要，否则不会恢复试验华盛顿确实这样做了，但军备控制专家表示，在乌克兰和中东战事激烈、紧张局势严重之际，俄罗斯或美国的试验可能引发新的军备竞赛，并引发其他国家的更多试验。 p>;

;CNN 上个月发布的卫星图像显示，俄罗斯、美国和中国近年来都扩大了核试验场。

;

;美国能源部上周表示，它已进行了< a href="https://www.energy.gov/nnsa/articles/nnsa-conducts-experiment-improve-us-ability-detect-foreign-nuclear-explosions-0#:~:text=The%20experiment%20will %20help%20validate,radiotracer%20samplers%2C%20and%20meteorological%20sensors" target="_blank">;化学爆炸;在内华达州的试验场“以提高美国探测低当量核爆炸的能力”。

;

;外交部副部长谢尔盖·里亚布科夫在周三投票前对俄罗斯立法者表示，内华达州爆炸“无疑是一个政治信号”。

;

;“正如我们的总统所说，我们必须保持警惕，如果美国准备开始核试验，我们也必须以同样的方式做出反应。”他说。

;

;俄罗斯表示，其监测站将继续提供数据

;

;但在另一条评论中，俄新社援引里亚布科夫的话说，俄罗斯尚未准备好恢复与美国的核谈判

;

;如果不改变其立场，他说，“根本性的敌对路线”，“恢复有关战略稳定的对话，包括战略进攻性武器的话题和其他以前实行的形式的话题，是根本不可能的”。

;

;俄罗斯指责华盛顿试图通过在战争中武装乌克兰来对其造成“战略失败”。美国表示正在帮助基辅保卫自己。

;

;缺乏核对话使人们对《新削减战略武器条约》的命运产生了疑问，该条约限制了俄罗斯和美国可以部署的战略弹头的数量。

;

;俄罗斯今年暂停了该条约，该条约将于 2026 年到期，导致两国没有任何剩余的双边核武器协议。

;

;里亚布科夫表示，莫斯科已收到来自俄罗斯的一份非正式备忘录。华盛顿在军备控制问题上正在研究它，但它“没有新颖的元素”。

; Wed, 25 Oct 2023 18:25:02 +0800 Sam Bankman-Fried might risk testifying in criminal trial, experts sayhttps://reuters.com/article/usa-bankmanfried-testify/sam-bankman-fried-might-risk-testifying-in-criminal-trial-experts-say-idUSKBN31P0Y2
;;2023-10-25T10:11:55Z;
;;
;;Indicted FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried leaves the United States Courthouse in New York City, US, July 26, 2023. REUTERS/Amr Alfiky/File Photo;
;

;Sam Bankman-Fried has little to lose by bucking conventional wisdom and taking the stand at his criminal fraud trial, following weeks of testimony that he stole billions of dollars from unwitting customers of his FTX cryptocurrency exchange.

;

;Doing so would expose Bankman-Fried to probing cross-examination by prosecutors who would come armed with documents, messages and testimony from cooperating witnesses that they can use to attack his credibility.

;

;But given Bankman-Fried's penchant for risk, his willingness to speak publicly about the charges and ;prosecutors' unflattering portrayal; of him at the trial, he may bet that he can convince just one juror that he did not intend to commit fraud, legal experts said.

;

;Bankman-Fried's lawyers have said he is considering taking the stand.

;

;"It's not irrational to testify, if you think you are going down because the evidence is so overwhelming," defense attorney Ilene Jaroslaw said.

;

;Defendants are not required to testify in criminal cases, but sometimes do so in a bid to raise doubt that prosecutors have proved their case.

;

;Elizabeth Holmes ;took the stand; at her criminal trial, testifying over several days that she did not intend to defraud investors in her blood-testing startup, Theranos. Holmes was ultimately convicted on four out of 11 counts and sentenced to more than 11 years in prison.

;

;For Bankman-Fried to be convicted of fraud, prosecutors must show beyond a reasonable doubt that he intended to defraud FTX customers or investors. The 12 jurors must agree unanimously to return a verdict.

;

;Prosecutors are expected to rest their case on Thursday. Bankman-Fried stands accused of looting customer money to make speculative venture investments, donate to political candidates, and repay lenders to his hedge fund Alameda Research.

;

;A spokesperson for Bankman-Fried declined to comment.

;

;The Massachusetts Institute of Technology graduate has pleaded not guilty. At trial, his lawyers have argued that he never intended to defraud anyone, and that many functions at the fledgling crypto exchange - including risk management - were "works in progress."

;

;The 31-year-old former billionaire has already taken an unusual approach for a criminal defendant. Instead of laying low after he was charged, he published blog posts on his view of what went wrong and met with several journalists.

;

;"I didn't steal funds, and I certainly didn't stash billions away," Bankman-Fried ;wrote in January;, a month after his arrest on US fraud charges.

;

;Taking the stand carries the risk that he will be confronted with those media appearances as well as his use of social media.

;

;But Bankman-Fried has a lower-than-average fear of risk, according to trial testimony.

;

;Whereas most people are risk-averse, Bankman-Fried views himself as "risk-neutral," Caroline Ellison, former co-chief of Alameda, said on the stand.

;

;Ellison was one of three former members of Bankman-Fried's inner circle who testified at trial, saying they committed crimes with him and adding to a portrayal by the government that Bankman-Fried's attorneys have called a "cartoon of a villain."

;

;Mike Schachter, a defense attorney at Willkie Farr & Gallagher, said that, in some cases, taking the stand is the only way for a defendant to remove the "mask" put on them by prosecutors.

;

;Schachter represented Tom Barrack, a onetime private equity executive and fundraiser for former President Donald Trump, and Lebanese businessman Jean Boustani in separate, unrelated criminal cases.

;

;Both men took the stand at their trials and were ultimately acquitted.

;

;In both cases, he felt it was important for them to be ready to testify on every allegation jurors had heard at the trial.

;

;That level of preparedness is harder to achieve while in detention, where sleep is fleeting and the bus to court often leaves before dawn, he added.

;

;"It really requires laser concentration. And they won't even give you a cup of coffee," he said.

;

;Bankman-Fried has been held in Brooklyn's Metropolitan Detention Center since Aug. 11, when the judge overseeing the case ;jailed him; for likely tampering with witnesses.

;

;US District Judge Lewis Kaplan told Bankman-Fried that if he decides to testify, even if he hasn't planned it with his lawyers, all he needs to do is stand up at the end of the case.

;

;"You will be permitted to do so, regardless of whatever advice you have received," he said.

; Wed, 25 Oct 2023 18:25:02 +0800 US zoo saving endangered red wolf, one dental checkup at a timehttps://reuters.com/article/usa-red-wolves/us-zoo-saving-endangered-red-wolf-one-dental-checkup-at-a-time-idUSKBN31P0YA
;;2023-10-25T10:13:58Z;
;

;The endangered red wolf, the lone wolf species native only to the United States, is slowly coming back thanks to a breeding and reintroduction program that also takes special care of the wolves' teeth.

;

;The Tacoma-based Point Defiance Zoo is conducting dental exams and teeth-cleaning in its managed care program. Broken teeth "would prevent them from eating meat very well," said Karen Wolf, the zoo's head veterinarian.

;

;The fittingly named vet is helping bolster a population of only 270 red wolves known to exist, mostly in managed care or zoos. Just 20 live in the wild, roaming in three wildlife refuges in eastern North Carolina.

;

;During one recent checkup at a facility in a wildlife preserve 60 miles (100 km) south of Seattle, the sedated patient was a 9-year-old wolf known as 2077, the grandfather of six pups born earlier this year and the father of a wolf released into the wild.

;

;"He is quite a patriarch," Wolf said.

;

;The cinnamon-colored wolf, named 2077 by the US Fish & Wildlife Service as the 2,077th wolf entered into the program, received a thorough cleaning and x-rays, and a diseased molar was removed. The vets also administered vaccines and drew blood to assess its overall health.

;

;Meanwhile at an off-site breeding center, the most recent litter of pups yelped an off-key caterwaul into the forest.

;

;The animals in managed care tend to live longer than free-ranging red wolves, in part because they have annual exams and dental hygiene.

;

;The rare red wolves once ranged from New York to Texas, but by the late 1960s to 1970s a once thriving population was decimated. The wildlife service classified it as threatened with extinction in 1967.

;

;As recently as the 1950s and 1960s, the US wildlife service had an eradication program that killed wolves to protect people and other animals, only later understanding that apex predators were necessary to maintain a healthy ecosystem, said Natalie Davis, zoo curator and part of the Association of Zoos & Aquariums' program to save red wolves from extinction. It has introduced seven wolves into the wild in North Carolina this year.

;

;Three of those released came from the Point Defiance Zoo program, including a pup born April 13.
